9977324.subtopic: Curriculum & Instruction,Health Monitoring & Evaluation,Gender and Education,Primary Education,Teaching and Learning

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Third Education
            Project for Paraguay was to increase primary and secondary
            educational opportunities and to adapt them to the needs of
            an expanding economy. The project was satisfactorily
            implemented with an overrun of only 5.2 percent of the
            original cost. The project was completed within the
            estimated time with savings. To utilize these savings the
            Bank and the Borrower agreed to construct 11 primary schools
            in the Asuncion area and to extend the original closing date
            about one year. Success of project implementation may be
            attributed primarily to the fact that a Project
            Implementation Unit (PIU) staffed with a stable cadre of
            full-time qualified professionals, who had been given ample
            autonomy by the Minister of Education, had been carrying out
            its duties since implementation of the First Education
            Project in 1973 and was thoroughly familiar with Bank
            guidelines and procedures.

docna.cdata!:
Paraguay - Third Education Project : Loan
            1346 - Loan Agreement - Conformed

display_title.display_title:
Paraguay - Third Education
            Project : Loan 1346 - Loan Agreement - Conformed

docna.cdata!:
Paraguay - Third Education Project : Credit
            0667 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

display_title.display_title:
Paraguay - Third Education
            Project : Credit 0667 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

abstracts.cdata!:
The Third Education Project will: (a)
            establish 83 rural community learning centers; (b) complete
            construction of 77 associated primary schools for 18,000
            students which were initiated by community financial effort;
            (c) provide functional buildings and equipment for workshops
            and laboratories for five lower secondary schools; (d)
            expand two existing multilateral secondary schools with
            workshops and laboratories; (e) provide in-service training
            for about 2,700 teachers, school directors and supervisiors
            of project institutions; (f) print materials for the
            production of 10 textbook titles and related teaching
            guides; (g) assist the various departments in the Ministry
            of Education Departments to improve their efficiency in
            educational administration; (h) help the Ministry of
            Education complete an educational facilities survey and a
            school map; (i) assist the Government in carrying out a
            study on bilingual education; and (j) provide related
            technical assistance comprising eight man-years of
            specialist services and 27 man-years of fellowships for
            training abroad.
